awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An Eocene perspective on future recovery rates of climate and ocean chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
This projects provides a case study of a past climate event, called the Eocene Thermal Maximum-2 to constrain natural recovery rates of climate and ocean chemistry following massive carbon input into Earth's surface reservoirs. The study will allow new insight into past climate and ocean acidification processes that were hitherto unexplored, hence promoting the progress of science and advancing the field of climatology. Such insight is essential to providing the public, scientific leaders, and policy makers with a better understanding of the consequences of unabated CO2 emissions for global climate, ocean carbonate chemistry, and marine ecosystems. Moreover, the project integrates research and educational activities by introducing this information directly into secondary school and college curricula and popular journals. The project fosters education for graduate and undergraduate students from ethnically diverse populations, while conducting cutting-edge research at the same time. The outcome of this study will advancethe understanding of the Earth system and hence improve forecasts of future climate change, which is beneficial to society.

Specifically, proxy records will be generated and used (d13C, d18O, %CaCO3, B/Ca, d11B) in combination with numerical modeling to determine natural recovery times for carbon cycle processes, temperature, and surface ocean acidification. The study will (1) provide fundamental insight into negative climate-carbon cycle feedbacks, (2) address important gaps in data coverage and understanding of Eocene hyperthermals, and (3) constrain critical parameter values needed for future climate-carbon cycle simulations.

por.por_cntn:
One of the main goals of current climate research is predicting short-term climate change (decades to centuries) in response to rising anthropogenic greenhouse gas forcing. However, equally important for the future of the Earth system is its recovery from such forcing events, i.e., the system's ability to restore conditions towards the pre-perturbation state. For example, negative climate system- and carbon cycle feedbacks tend to dampen increases in temperature and atmospheric greenhouse gases. Unfortunately, little is currently known about the nature and strength of the critical negative feedbacks over longer time scales. The feedbacks are poorly constrained in current climate-carbon cycle models due to a lack of adequate model test data from suitable climate records in the past. Here we studied a climate event called the Eocene Thermal Maximum-2 (ETM-2) to constrain recovery rates of climate and ocean chemistry following massive carbon input into Earth's surface reservoirs. Using an integrated model-data approach, we generate and use ETM-2 proxy records for temperature and ocean chemistry in combination with numerical modeling to determine recovery times for carbon cycle processes, temperature, and surface ocean acidification.

Briefly, in this project, we have investigated possible mechanisms responsible for observed long-term climate-carbon cycle trends by using a novel approach that features a full-fledged ocean chemistry model. Furthermore, we have generated the first records of surface ocean acidification for ETM-2. Our reconstructed salinization during ETM-2 is consistent with the hypothesis of enhanced meridional vapor transport and increased subtropical aridity in a warmer world. Our model results on ocean biogeochemistry indicate that a redox-controlled carbon-phosphorus feedback is capable of producing enhanced organic carbon sequestration during large carbon emission events. We have also presented new astronomical calculations that show exceptional agreement with geologic data.

Our study provides fundamental insight into negative climate-carbon cycle feedbacks, addresses an important gap in data coverage and understanding of past climate events, and constrains critical parameter values needed for future climate-carbon cycle simulations. Our results on carbon input and surface ocean chemistry changes can be used to understand effects of carbon dioxide emission on future changes in ocean chemistry. As such they are relevant to the general public and policy decisions. We provide a historic/geologic perspective on the current human activities and conclude that future ecosystem disruptions are likely to exceed the relatively limited effects observed during the Eocene climate events studied here. Hence this project provides important insight into the short- and long-term impacts of anthropogenic greenhouse gases on climate and ocean acidification. Such information is essential to providing the public, scientific leaders, and policy makers with a better understanding of the consequences of unabated carbon emissions for global climate, ocean chemistry, and marine ecosystems. Moreover, the project integrates research and educational activities on global warming and ocean acidification by introducing this information directly into secondary school and college curricula and popular journals. The project fosters education for graduate and undergraduate students from the ethnically diverse population at the University of Hawaii and the University of California at Santa Cruz, while conducting cutting-edge research at the same time.
